strategy.title: Strategy
strategy.description: Free State AG is an established producer of green electricity in Switzerland and operates modern solar power plants. In the medium term, the company aims to build a diverse and balanced portfolio of renewable energies with a total installed capacity of 59 megawatts*. The goal is to position itself as one of the leading operators of renewable energies in Switzerland.
strategy.diversification: A central element of the investment strategy is diversification. It minimizes risks in the areas of market conditions, legal frameworks and availability of generation types.
strategy.future: In the future, electricity production from solar energy should account for about 20‚Äì30 percent of the company's revenue. Free State AG invests exclusively in plants with mature technology that are either already in operation or have full approval at the start of construction. The sale of power plants is not part of the business model.
strategy.synergies: In addition to further acquisitions, Free State maximizes synergies in plant operation to continuously increase operational efficiency. The expansion of a diversified portfolio should sustainably promote revenue and profit development.

investing.title: Invest sustainably
investing.description: With an investment in renewable energies, you are betting on sustainable and future-proof value creation. Free State AG offers you the opportunity to participate in solar power plants and other environmentally friendly projects. Benefit from stable returns, a growing market and an active contribution to the energy transition. Our experience and our focus on mature technologies guarantee you security and success ‚Äì for a greener future.

form.title: Order documents free of charge
form.description: Do you want to make a positive contribution to the environment and society? Request our documents free of charge now and find out how you can actively contribute to the energy transition with sustainable energy solutions and investments in renewable energies. Simply fill out the form, and we will send you the requested documents directly. Use this opportunity to inform yourself comprehensively and shape a green and successful future together with us!
form.privacy: I hereby confirm that I have read the privacy policy.

invest.question: Can I invest in Free State Energie AG?
invest.answer: If you are a person with residence in Switzerland and qualify as a qualified investor by investing funds or knowledge, then yes. Every person with residence in Switzerland who has a Swiss bank account and experience in the investment world can subscribe to shares under the officially set conditions of the capital increase.

deposit.question: Where are my Free State AG shares deposited?
deposit.answer: The shares of Free State Energie AG are digitized and are issued by Schaffhauser Kantonalbank AG and distributed to a deposit account at your bank. It is possible that your bank values them at a price of 0 (zero), as the company is not yet listed on the stock exchange.

listed.question: Is Free State Energie AG listed on a public stock exchange?
listed.answer: No, currently the company is privately owned and is not listed on a stock exchange. Each shareholder has full shareholder rights including dividend rights. Free State AG intends to go public in the near future, but this depends heavily on the market situation, company development and the number of investors.

hero.title: How it works
hero.subtitle: A heat pump works in reverse, extracting ambient heat for heating.

construction.title: Construction of a heat pump
construction.description: A heat pump includes a heat source, the pump unit, and a heat distribution system. It operates in a closed cycle: the evaporator extracts heat, the compressor increases its temperature, the condenser transfers it to the heating system, and the expansion valve resets the cycle.

howItWorks.title:
This is how the
heat pump works
howItWorks.subtitle: A heat pump has three components: the heat source, pump unit, and distribution system.

heatPumpTypes.title: Heat pump types

heatPumpTypesDetail.title: How these three heat pumps work:

1.title: Ground source heat pump (geothermal)
1.description: Uses stable ground temperature for highly efficient heating. Requires drilling, higher investment, and municipal approval.

2.title: Water-to-water heat pump
2.description: Uses groundwater or surface water for very high efficiency. Needs suitable water conditions and official permits.

3.title: Air-to-water heat pump
3.description: Extracts heat from ambient air to heat the home. Simpler installation and lower upfront cost.

whichHeatPump.title: Which heat pump do I need?
whichHeatPump.description:
Air-to-water heat pumps are easy to install, cost-effective, and the most common in Switzerland.

Ground source heat pumps are highly efficient but require more installation effort, while water source systems are extremely efficient yet rarely approved due to regulations. The best option depends on your specific property.
whichHeatPump.stat: In 2016, almost 67% of all heat pumps sold in Switzerland were air-to-water heat pumps.

hero.title:
How a solar
power system works

section.title: How it works
section.subtitle: How does a solar power system work?
section.description:
A solar power system converts the radiant energy of sunlight into usable electricity. The solar modules on the roof capture the sun's rays with the help of solar cells and thus produce direct current (DC). This DC is then converted into alternating current (AC), i.e., electrical current, by an inverter.

Solar power is therefore electricity generated by the photovoltaic effect in solar cells. No exhaust emissions are produced during electricity generation.
section.imageCaption: The following graphic shows how a solar system works, including the positioning of the most important elements in the house:
section.imageAlt: Diagram showing how a solar power system works in a house

solarPanel.title: How a solar panel works
solarPanel.description: Solar panels can convert sunlight into electricity. This is made possible by semiconductors (silicon), which conduct electricity. As soon as sunlight shines on the solar panel, electrons are excited. The electrons then move through the layers of the solar panel to the inverter. The electrons transport the electricity to where the energy is needed. Depending on demand, the energy goes directly to the end users (light bulb, PC, battery, etc.), where the electricity is available for later use.
solarPanel.infoCard: Solar modules ‚Äì also called solar panels ‚Äì consist of many small solar cells. When many solar modules are connected together, it is called a solar power system.

whichSystem.title: Which solar system is right for me?
whichSystem.description: When choosing the right solar system, you should consider not only your energy consumption but also the size and current characteristics of your roof. You can also choose between a roof-mounted or roof-integrated system, as well as various solar panel colors.

householdConsumption.title: Household consumption
householdConsumption.description: First, you need to determine your household's annual electricity consumption. The solar system should at least cover the household's electricity consumption.

roofArea.title: Size of the roof area
roofArea.description: The roof area determines how many solar panels, and therefore the maximum power output, can be installed. The panels must be arranged in such a way that they cover your household's electricity consumption.

requiredOutput.title: Required photovoltaic system output per household
requiredOutput.description: The electrical output of a photovoltaic system is measured in kWp (kilowatt peak). In Switzerland, depending on location and efficiency, an average of 800-1,300 kilowatt-hours (kWh) can be generated per kWp per year. The following table shows the average required output for different household sizes and the resulting size of the solar system.

headers.size: Size of the solar power system

selectionCriteria.title: Further selection criteria
selectionCriteria.quote: "Generally, we recommend aligning the size of the PV system with your consumption or choosing a larger system."

roofCondition.title: Roof condition
roofCondition.description: A solar power system has a lifespan of 30 years, meaning the roof should be designed to last at least that long. If the roof is already porous or older than 40 years, an integrated roof system is a good option.

onRoofOrInRoof.title: On-roof or in-roof
onRoofOrInRoof.description:
In Switzerland, rooftop solar systems are the most popular. The solar modules are mounted on a substructure, leaving the original roof intact. Rooftop systems are cost-effective and can be installed very quickly.

With an integrated roof system, the photovoltaic system replaces the roof covering. This option can therefore be considered for older roofs that need renovation or for new construction. The solar modules are available in various colors. Color coordination can create a particularly elegant look. Integrated roof systems are approximately 20 percent more expensive than on-roof systems. However, no roof covering is required.

desiredAppearance.title: Desired appearance
desiredAppearance.description: Helion offers solar modules in classic silver-grey, anthracite and, upon request, in other color shades.

installation.title: Installation of a solar system
installation.subtitle: The installation costs are fully included in the price of the solar system.
installation.description: We install the system with our team of experienced professionals: electricians, roofers, carpenters, plumbers, and sheet metal workers. Depending on the size of the solar system, installation takes between 2 days and one week.

maintenance.title: Maintenance of a solar system
maintenance.description:
We ensure the highest quality in component selection and installation. Our photovoltaic systems have an average lifespan of 30 years and require very little maintenance. You receive a 20-25 year warranty from the module manufacturer. Only the inverter needs to be replaced every 12 years.

Optionally, you can take out a monitoring contract with FreeState to ensure you are covered for the entire 30-year lifespan of your system. Furthermore, we guarantee the energy yield for the first 10 years, thus securing the long-term operation of your PV system (see our terms and conditions for full details).

installation.bottomNote: At FreeState, you get a top-quality photovoltaic system at affordable prices. Starting from just CHF 10,000, including subsidies and tax savings, you can become your own electricity producer and thus independent of rising electricity costs. And last but not least: you'll be making a positive contribution to the environment.

batteryStorage.title: Optional: Battery storage
batteryStorage.description: A battery storage system and a heat pump can be used to complement a photovoltaic system. These two additional components can significantly increase the self-consumption of energy in an apartment building or a single-family home ‚Äì and thus optimize the use of the solar system.
batteryStorage.infoCard: The cost of a solar power system depends primarily on the surface area and the power output (kWp). Even at the time of purchase, solar modules can differ in power output by up to 20%.

costSection.title: How much does a solar power system cost?
costSection.paragraph1: A photovoltaic system on a small roof of a detached house can now be installed for as little as CHF 19,500 (including subsidies and tax savings). This is a guideline figure, as various factors influence the price of the photovoltaic system.
costSection.paragraph2: The net investment costs for the photovoltaic system are significantly reduced by <subsidies>subsidies</subsidies> ‚Äì depending on the canton, these subsidies can amount to several thousand Swiss francs. Helion handles all registrations and applications, ensuring you receive the maximum possible subsidies.
costSection.infoCard: The cost of a solar power system depends mainly on the following factors: roof size and output, choice of solar modules, material costs (inverter + substructure) and scaffolding including fuse box.

pricingSection.title: Cost of a solar system in CHF
pricingSection.note: Acquisition costs per household after 30% deduction of subsidies & 25% tax savings

idealTime.title: The ideal time to buy
idealTime.description:
Due to high demand for photovoltaic systems, the solar market has seen considerable activity in recent years. Why is now the best time to buy a solar system?

However, due to high demand, the authorities are reaching their financial limits. Consequently, subsidies for solar power systems are decreasing annually.

The best and cheapest time to buy a solar power system is right now. The longer you wait, the less funding will be available to you.
idealTime.infoCard: Photovoltaic systems now cost only 20% of what they did ten years ago. At the same time, subsidies are decreasing annually.

block1.description: The payback period for solar power systems depends on various factors. Generally, solar power systems pay for themselves within 8 to 12 years.

block2.infoCard: To calculate the amortization period of your photovoltaic system in years, the purchase and installation costs are divided by the sum of income and depreciation.

privacyPolicy.title: Privacy Policy
privacyPolicy.subtitle: How we handle your personal data
privacyPolicy.intro: The operators of these pages take the protection of your personal data very seriously. We treat your personal data confidentially and in accordance with the statutory data protection regulations and this privacy policy.

dataCollection.title: Data Collection on Our Website
dataCollection.content:
The data processing on this website is carried out by the website operator. Their contact details can be found in the legal notice of this website.

Your data is collected either when you provide it to us (e.g., data entered in a contact form), or automatically by our IT systems when you visit the website. This is primarily technical data (e.g., internet browser, operating system, or time of page access). This data is collected automatically as soon as you enter our website.

automaticData.title: Automatically Collected Data
automaticData.content:
When you visit our website, our web servers temporarily store each access in a log file. The following data is recorded and stored until automatic deletion:

‚Ä¢ IP address of the requesting computer
‚Ä¢ Date and time of access
‚Ä¢ Name and URL of the retrieved file
‚Ä¢ Website from which access was made (referrer URL)
‚Ä¢ Browser used and, if applicable, the operating system of your computer
‚Ä¢ Name of your access provider

cookies.title: Cookies
cookies.content:
Our website uses cookies. Cookies are small text files that are stored on your device. They do not cause any damage.

We use cookies to make our website user-friendly. Some cookies remain stored on your device until you delete them. They enable us to recognize your browser on your next visit.

If you do not want this, you can set up your browser so that it informs you about the setting of cookies and you only allow this in individual cases.

analytics.title: Web Analytics (Matomo)
analytics.content:
This website uses Matomo for web analytics. Matomo uses cookies that are stored on your computer and enable an analysis of the use of the website. The information generated by the cookie about your use of this website is stored on our server in Switzerland.

The IP address is anonymized immediately after processing and before storage. You can prevent the storage of cookies by setting your browser software accordingly. We would like to point out, however, that in this case you may not be able to use all functions of this website to their full extent.

socialMedia.title: Social Media Plugins
socialMedia.content:
Our pages contain plugins from social networks (e.g., Twitter, Instagram). You can recognize these plugins by the respective logos. When you activate these plugins, a direct connection is established between your browser and the server of the respective social network.

We would like to point out that as the provider of the pages, we have no knowledge of the content of the transmitted data or its use by the social networks. For more information, please refer to the privacy policies of the respective networks.

googleMaps.title: Google Maps
googleMaps.content:
This website uses the Google Maps service. The provider is Google Ireland Limited. When you use Google Maps, information about your use of this website (including your IP address) is transmitted to a Google server and stored there.

For more information on the handling of user data, please refer to Google's privacy policy: https://policies.google.com/privacy

newsletter.title: Newsletter
newsletter.content:
If you would like to receive the newsletter offered on the website, we require an email address from you as well as information that allows us to verify that you are the owner of the email address provided.

The data entered in the newsletter registration form is processed exclusively on the basis of your consent (Art. 6 para. 1 lit. a GDPR). You can revoke your consent at any time. The legality of the data processing operations already carried out remains unaffected by the revocation.

userRights.title: Your Rights
userRights.content:
You have the right to receive information about the origin, recipients, and purpose of your stored personal data free of charge at any time. You also have the right to request the correction or deletion of this data.

If you have given your consent to data processing, you can revoke this consent at any time for the future. You also have the right to request the restriction of the processing of your personal data under certain circumstances.

You also have the right to lodge a complaint with the competent supervisory authority.

dataRetention.title: Data Retention
dataRetention.content: The data collected by us will be deleted after the contractual relationship has ended and the statutory retention periods have expired. If the data is required for the fulfillment of a contract or for the implementation of pre-contractual measures, early deletion of the data is only possible if contractual or legal obligations do not prevent deletion.

whySolarCarport.title: Why install solar panels on your carport?
whySolarCarport.description: A solar panel system on your carport lets you use sustainable energy while protecting your vehicle. It reduces dependence on rising electricity prices and supports climate protection. With custom-designed carports from Uninorm, you get maximum energy efficiency without sacrificing style.

evCharging.title: EV charging directly at your solar carport.
evCharging.description: Helion also offers a suitable charging station for your electric car, which can be integrated directly into your solar system. This way, you can efficiently use the electricity produced by your carport for your journeys.

installationTime.question: How long does it take to install a solar panel system on my carport?
installationTime.answer: Installation typically takes 1-2 days, depending on local conditions.

subsidies.question: Are there any special subsidies for solar carports?
subsidies.answer: Yes, in Switzerland there are various subsidy programs for solar installations, including on carports. These include one-time remuneration from Pronovo and possible cantonal subsidies. We will be happy to advise you on the available options.

electricityProduction.question: How much electricity does a solar panel on a carport produce?
electricityProduction.answer: The electricity production depends on the size of your carport and the number of solar panels. A single carport with 6 panels produces approximately 2,539 kWh per year, while a double carport with 12 panels produces approximately 5,078 kWh per year.

evCharging.question: Can I use the solar power I produce to charge my electric car?
evCharging.answer: Absolutely! With an integrated charging station, you can use the solar power generated on your carport directly to charge your electric car. This allows you to drive CO₂-neutral and save on fuel costs.

energyStorage.question: Can I store the generated energy?
energyStorage.answer: Yes, with a battery storage system, you can store excess solar energy and use it later, for example in the evening or on cloudy days. We offer suitable storage solutions that can be seamlessly integrated with your solar carport.

whatIs.title: What is an energy storage?

The energy storage system stores the excess energy produced by the photovoltaic system during the day. Thanks to the battery storage, solar power is also available in the evenings, at night, and in the mornings.

howItWorks.title:
How does an energy
storage system work?
howItWorks.description:
Solar energy can be used directly, stored in a battery, or fed into the grid. Excess power charges the battery, supplying the home from evening to morning; grid power is used only when the battery is empty.

Optimal performance depends on the right system and battery size, ideally combined with intelligent energy control.

perfectCombination.title: The perfect combination
perfectCombination.description: Configure your own solar system in minutes with our solar calculator and receive a concrete offer immediately:
perfectCombination.ctaText: Get a free, no-obligation quote now!

whenMakesSense.title: When does a battery storage system make sense?
whenMakesSense.description:
Solar panels produce the most electricity at midday, when household consumption is usually low.

Without storage, excess energy is fed into the grid at low compensation rates. Maximizing self-consumption increases profitability and reduces electricity costs.
whenMakesSense.infoCard: With a suitable storage solution, self-consumption can be increased from 30-35% to around 70%

installation.title: Battery Storage Installation
installation.description: Based on your specific situation and needs, our experts will recommend either the AC or DC system. Installation is carried out by our experienced specialists, all of whom are certified by the manufacturer. Helion automatically registers each installed battery with Inobat, ensuring the proper disposal of your aging energy storage system

solarSeason.title: Start the Solar Season Right
solarSeason.description: About 80% of yearly solar energy is generated between March and October, making it the most productive period for solar panels. A system check at the start of the season is recommended, as winter may have caused damage. While owners can spot obvious issues themselves, a professional inspection helps detect hidden damage, performance losses, or soiling from birds, leaves, or dust.

highestLevel.title: Service at the highest level
highestLevel.description:
We offer our solar panel and battery storage service throughout Switzerland. Our experienced service technicians are regionally based and can therefore be on-site quickly. We can even resolve minor malfunctions or damage within a few working days.

Our services apply both to photovoltaic systems and battery storage systems built by us and to systems installed by third parties.

selfCheck.title: The solar system self-check
selfCheck.description: You can perform an initial check yourself. For a thorough examination, we recommend that you consult one of our specialists.

items.yield: Check your solar system's yield via the app or web interface and compare it with last year's data. If you notice unusual changes, contact us so we can investigate.
items.panels: If it's safe to do so, inspect the panels for weather damage or heavy soiling. Regular maintenance helps detect issues early and prevent more serious problems.

expanded.label: Without a maintenance contract
expanded.description: No maintenance contract is required for the system check. This offer applies to photovoltaic systems up to 19.99 kWp.

maintenance.title: Our maintenance services
maintenance.description:
FreeState offers maintenance contracts with different levels of coverage: monitoring, inspection, and inspection with full system check. Included services vary by package.

We service both FreeState and third-party solar systems. Battery storage systems are fully supported.

items.notification: Immediate notification: You receive prompt error alerts with clear recommendations for next steps.
items.visualization: Visualization: Your system's performance, self-consumption, and status are monitored and displayed 24/7.
items.storage: Storage optimization: Continuous monitoring helps maximize the efficiency of your energy storage.
items.faultSupport: Failure & Fault Support: We detect, analyze, and quickly resolve system faults and connection issues.
items.includedServices: Included services: Warranty-covered repairs and GSM data transmission costs are included in your contract.
items.dataSecurity: Data security: Monitoring logs provide documented evidence to support warranty claims.

hero.title: Repowering
hero.description: Upgrade your solar system with repowering for higher efficiency, more output, and long-term performance.

repoweringCta.title: Solar repowering. Same area. Higher yield.

bullets.1: Replace outdated components to increase output without using more space.
bullets.2: Improve reliability by upgrading faulty or aging parts.
bullets.3: Boost self-consumption and reduce costs with modern, efficient technology.

customerBenefits.title: The Customer Benefits
customerBenefits.description: With FreeState, you get smart energy management for maximum efficiency.

heatPump.title: Heat Pump
heatPump.description: They benefit from low heating costs.

quoteForm.title: Get your free repowering offer here.
quoteForm.callbackLabel: Please call me back next week for a free initial consultation.

whatIsRepowering.question: What does photovoltaic repowering mean?
whatIsRepowering.answer: Repowering upgrades your existing PV system with modern components to increase performance, efficiency, and lifespan.

whenWorthwhile.question: When is repowering worthwhile and what advantages does it offer?
whenWorthwhile.answer: Repowering is worthwhile when your system is over 10‚Äì15 years old, showing reduced output, or when modern technology can significantly boost performance on the same area.

whichComponents.question: Which components need to be replaced during repowering?
whichComponents.answer: Typically solar modules, inverters, and cabling are replaced. The mounting structure can often be retained if it is still in good condition.

newInverter.question: Do I need a new inverter for a repowering project?
newInverter.answer: In most cases, yes. Older inverters are often incompatible with modern, higher-output modules and lack current efficiency standards.

substructure.question: Can the substructure remain?
substructure.answer: Often yes, provided it is structurally sound and compatible with the new modules. Our experts will assess this during the on-site inspection.

heatPumpsEv.question: Repowering for heat pumps and EV chargers?
heatPumpsEv.answer: Repowering can be combined with heat pump integration and EV charging solutions to maximize your self-consumption and overall energy efficiency.

howItWorks.question: How does a solar repowering project work?
howItWorks.answer: We start with an on-site assessment, design the optimal upgrade, handle all permits and installation, and ensure everything is commissioned and monitored.

costsPayback.question: Repowering costs & payback?
costsPayback.answer: Costs depend on system size and components replaced. Thanks to higher yields and current subsidies, payback periods are typically 8‚Äì12 years.

legalRegulations.question: Are there legal regulations for repowering?
legalRegulations.answer: Yes, building permits and grid connection regulations may apply. We handle all regulatory requirements as part of our service.

subsidies.question: Are there subsidies available for repowering?
subsidies.answer: Yes, repowering projects can qualify for federal and cantonal subsidies. We help you identify and apply for all available funding.

existingKev.question: What will happen to existing KEV installations?
existingKev.answer: Existing KEV contracts remain valid. However, repowering may affect the terms, so careful planning is essential to preserve your feed-in tariff.

kevExpiry.question: What happens when the existing KEV expires?
kevExpiry.answer: After KEV expiry, you can switch to self-consumption optimization or negotiate a new feed-in tariff with your energy provider.

feedInTariff.question: How does repowering affect the feed-in tariff (excluding KEV)?
feedInTariff.answer: Repowering may change your feed-in tariff conditions. We advise on the best strategy to maximize your returns.

optimalTime.question: When is the optimal time for repowering?
optimalTime.answer: The best time is when your system's output has noticeably declined, components are reaching end-of-life, or when subsidies make the investment attractive.

selfConsumption.question: Can I optimize my self-consumption through repowering?
selfConsumption.answer: Absolutely. Modern modules produce more power, and combined with battery storage, you can significantly increase your self-consumption rate.

notBuiltByFreeState.question: Can I order repowering even if my system wasn't built by FreeState?
notBuiltByFreeState.answer: Yes, we offer repowering for all existing solar systems regardless of the original installer.

oldPanels.question: What happens to my old solar panels?
oldPanels.answer: Old panels are professionally recycled in accordance with Swiss regulations. We handle the complete disposal process.

taxBenefits.question: Can I claim tax benefits for a repowering project?
taxBenefits.answer: Yes, repowering investments are generally tax-deductible in Switzerland as energy-saving renovation measures.

addSolarAbo.question: Is it possible to simply add a SolarAbo to the existing system?
addSolarAbo.answer: Yes, in many cases we can integrate your existing system into a SolarAbo model, combining repowering with our all-inclusive service.

Nibe heat pumps stand out for high energy efficiency and low operating costs, using renewable sources like air, ground, and water. They offer a wide product range with advanced inverter technology and smart controls for precise, user-friendly operation.

Designed for sustainability, quiet performance, and long lifespan, Nibe systems are reliable, low-maintenance, and suitable for both new builds and renovations, backed by comprehensive service and support.

howHeatPumpWorks.title:
How does a heat
pump work?
howHeatPumpWorks.description: Heat pumps are highly efficient, quickly installed sustainable heating systems that extract energy from air, ground, or water‚Äîmost commonly as air-to-water models‚Äîoffering a reliable alternative to fossil fuels.

advantages.title:
Advantages of
your heat pump
advantages.description: Unlike oil heating, heat pumps emit very little CO‚ÇÇ and operate highly efficiently, generating four to five units of heat from one unit of electricity.

idealCombination.title:
Heat pump + photovoltaics:
the ideal combination
idealCombination.description: Although heat pumps require a higher upfront investment, they offer low operating costs and become even more economical with a photovoltaic system. Self-generated solar power is significantly cheaper than grid electricity, and higher self-consumption maximizes savings, as feed-in tariffs are usually low.

selfConsumption.title:

self-consumption
selfConsumption.description: Maximize the electricity you use yourself by adding a battery storage system, so excess solar power remains available when the sun isn't shining.

solar power

energyEfficiency.title:
Optimize your
energy efficiency
energyEfficiency.description: Solar power first supplies your household, heat pump, and EV, while excess energy is stored in a battery or fed into the grid. It can also heat domestic water, with smart controls optimizing distribution and maximizing system performance.

costsInstallation.title: Costs and installation
costsInstallation.description:
Focusing only on purchase price is short-sighted, as oil heating often costs more over time due to higher operating expenses. Heat pumps and photovoltaic systems last around 20 years, with subsidies and tax incentives available depending on your location.

Professional installation ensures optimal performance, whether integrating a new or existing solar system. With over 7,000 completed projects, we offer experience and tailored solutions‚Äîcontact us for a personalized quote.

How a solar
power system works

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.subtitle: How do large solar power plants work?
howItWorks.description: The solar panels on the roof capture sunlight using solar cells and produce direct current (DC). The inverter then converts this DC into alternating current (AC), which can be used for your electrical needs.
howItWorks.graphicDescription: The following graphic of a large commercial property explains how the solar system works and shows the placement of the most important elements in the building:

solarPanelWorks.title: How a solar panel works
solarPanelWorks.description:
Industrial buildings with large flat roofs are ideal for solar panels, allowing optimal tilt and orientation for maximum yield.

We analyze your annual consumption and roof area to determine the ideal system size and identify opportunities to align energy-intensive processes with solar production for greater savings.
solarPanelWorks.tip: The goal is to size the system to match your consumption and maximize self-use of solar power, especially during peak production.

inRoofOnRoof.title: In-roof or on-roof
inRoofOnRoof.description:
A photovoltaic system lasts 30+ years, so the roof must be in good condition and not require replacement soon. If the roof is over 40 years old, renovation is recommended.

When replacing a pitched roof, an integrated PV system reduces roofing costs and offers a cost-efficient way to combine a new roof with solar power.

storageSelfConsumption.title:

self-consumption
storageSelfConsumption.description: To maximize savings, increase self-consumption of your solar power. A battery stores excess daytime energy, so you can use it later instead of buying electricity from the grid.

selfConsumptionControl.title: Increase self-consumption with control
selfConsumptionControl.description: Our Smart Energy control system switches on energy-intensive appliances when solar power is available. This increases self-consumption, thus reducing the need for external coal and/or nuclear power.
selfConsumptionControl.tip: Storage solutions or control systems can increase your self-consumption by up to 80%.

bidirectionalCharging.title: Bidirectional Solar Charging
bidirectionalCharging.description: Bidirectional charging lets your EV store solar power and supply it back to your home, increasing self-consumption and energy independence. Vehicle and charger compatibility is required, and costs are currently higher than standard systems.

1.question: Can I charge my electric car using a household socket?
1.answer: While technically possible, charging from a standard household socket is slow and not recommended for regular use. A dedicated wallbox provides faster, safer, and more efficient charging for your electric vehicle.

2.question: What charging power do I need?
2.answer: For home use, 11 kW is typically sufficient and covers most daily driving needs overnight. If you have higher mileage requirements, a 22 kW charger offers faster charging times.

3.question: What do AC and DC mean?
3.answer: AC (alternating current) is the standard for home charging, using a wallbox with up to 22 kW. DC (direct current) is used for fast charging stations, offering much higher power levels but requiring specialized and more expensive equipment.

4.question: What do the different plug types mean?
4.answer: Type 2 is the European standard for AC charging and is compatible with all modern EVs. CCS (Combined Charging System) combines Type 2 with DC fast charging capability, making it the most versatile connector available.

5.question: What cable length do I need?
5.answer: The ideal cable length depends on where your charging station is installed relative to your parking spot. Typically, a 5-meter cable is sufficient for most home installations, but 7.5 meters provides more flexibility.

hero.title: Bidirectional Charging Station
hero.description: Bidirectional charging turns your EV into energy storage, supplying power when needed or most valuable.
